author: Jon Moody
title: OFFICIAL: Arsenal have been by far the most injured team in recent Premier League history
text:
Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain has had his fair share of injury problems (Photo: Getty) Share     
Make no mistake, this has been a torrid season for Arsenal fans. 
Where do we start? There was the epic Champions League implosion against Bayern Munich. A dreadful worst-ever run of form which put paid to their title hopes. The constant presence of the #WengerOut campaign. Alexis Sanchez hinting at a move to rivals Chelsea. 
Now in a further blow to Gooners everywhere, one of their biggest fears/complaints/frustrations (delete as applicable) with the club has been confirmed. 
Arsenal are the most injury-prone team in recent Premier League history. Hurts to hear, doesn't it? (Photo: Arsenal/Getty) 
The proof is indisputable, after a Sky Sports study of the 11 ever-present teams from the 2011/12 Premier League onwards has revealed the total days of injured players in that period. "I'm holding my leg, but actually I just needed some more hair gel" (Photo: Arsenal FC via Getty Images) 
Since August 2011, the Gunners have seen their players be out of action for an enormous 10,285 days - over 700 (almost two years!) more than their nearest injury rivals Manchester United. The Red Devils have suffered 9,600 days worth of injured players. Debuchy in pain after dislocating his shoulder (Photo: REUTERS) 
Gooners have long believed that injuries to key players in certain seasons have cost them the title and this does little to allay their frustration - particularly when you consider that Chelsea have had the smallest amount of injury days with just 4,559. That's right Theo - Arsenal players have spent almost two years more injured than anyone else (Photo: Getty Images) 
Take a look at the numbers in full: Total days of injured players since 2011/12 
It also may not come as a surprise to hear that in terms of individual player absences, Arsenal take the top two spots in this as well, with Jack Wilshere missing 884 days and Abou Diaby spending 858 days in the physio room. Jack Wilshere is preparing for another long lay-off (Photo: Reuters) Abou Diaby's broken ankle in 2006 led to injury problems throughout his career (Photo: AFP) 
Other big names who somewhat unsurprisingly feature in the injury list include Andy Carroll, Phil Jones, Vincent Kompany and Daniel Sturridge. 
The full breakdown of players is as such: Total days missed injured since start of 2011/12 
We're sure every team will point to "what ifs" with certain player injuries, but perhaps none more so than Arsenal. We just wonder what Arsene's thoughts on these new stats are? Like us on Facebook
